name: 施欣文
objective:
本課程旨在引導學生如何以批評的角度閱讀小說。課程討論有兩個重點：（一）小說的技巧：如情節、結構、人物塑造、敘事者與敘事策略、背景鋪陳、象徵與意象等。（二）小說與文學理論的關係：如何將文學理論運用到小說的閱讀與分析。

British and American Fiction is a fascinating and inexhaustible subject. In this course, after a brief background in the first week or two, we will spend our time on four novels. Jane Eyre, Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland (and perhaps its sequel Through the Looking-Glass), Huckleberry Finn, and 1984, are books that people in Britain or the U.S. would be nearly as likely to pick up for fun as they would be to read them in class. They’re also books that almost everyone knows something about—even if individuals haven’t read the book. Knowing these books and the context they came out of will give you the ability to understand many ideas that are central to British and American identity and culture. 

Through informal investigations and in-class activities, you will learn the literary and historical context of the novel in each era. How has fiction changed over time? How did the purpose of writing change? How have tastes changed? And why are these changes important?
schedule:
The first week will be devoted to setting up the course, but many of you are already quite well-prepared because you have just taken the survey on British and American literature. After this, we will spend several weeks reading Jane Eyre; one hour of our class time each week will be spent reading Alice's Adventures in Wonderland aloud and discussing it. 

Later in the course we will read Huckleberry Finn, and we will end with 1984. 

There is no midterm exam, but there is a final.
scorePolicy:
In-class Writing and Reading Quizzes: 30%
Close Readings: 30%
Final: 25%
In-class Activities and Participation: 15%
materials:
Jane Eyre (Charlotte Brontë)
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass (Lewis Carroll)
